Hey guys, interesting discussion.  Now that I'm back from Cali I can
tell you a bit about the reasoning that went into my handling of
speciation.

Let me just explain up front what was going on with N being set to 1.
 It probably makes sense to you that in pole balancing, where
topologies do tend to have under 20 connections, setting N to 1 is
fine.  In fact, I found it easier to get it working with N set to 1
because the significance of a connection is not really proportional to
the size of a genome when genomes are small.  So adding a gene to a
genome of length 3 isn't really more significant than adding a gene to
a genome of length 6 in terms of how important that new connection may
be to the network's functionality.

Now when we start talking about larger genomes, it may make sense to
use N.  In the robot duel, it is true that genomes became larger than
200 connections or even 300 sometimes.  But we kept N set to 1.  Why?
 Because I felt that even in large genomes, a single new connection
(or a few new connections) can be quite significant, and should have
an opportunity to be protected just as in small genomes.  Also, we
were using the dynamic speciation theshold (let's call it DST), i.e.
NEAT was moving around the threshold to keep a constant number of
species.
But that still doesn't settle whether or not N would have been useful.

The truth is this is a research issue.  There should be experiments
done on large genomes with N clamped to 1, and without.  And we could
see the effect.  I included N in the forumlai in my papers because it
is clearly important conceptually if not in practice.  But I do regret
if it caused confusion.  Although- perhaps that confusion will inspire
some research.

I think in NEAT it's hard to say that as you add genes they are less
significant in impact.  (Because that is the underlying assumption of
normalizing with N).  Perhaps this is the case, but I'm not sure.  I
guess with *extremely* large networks, it is true, like over size
1,000- but at what size does it begin to be true?  

Now I'll respond to some questions below...

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Derek James" <blue5432@y...> wrote:
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Colin Green <cgreen@d...> wrote:
> > Ok now I've woken up a bit... yes I agree with you here. Although 
> one 
> > point I would like to make is that this only works for direct 
> encoding 
> > schemes, NEAT is ok because a NEAT chromosome is a direct
encoding 
> of a 
> > NN. If you start to consider indirect encoding (as in biology)
then 
> you 
> > find that small changes in the genetic make up can result in
large 
> > changes in the phenotype. The solution is to compare phenotypes - 
> which 
> > is something I didn't take into a account in my own code which IS 
> does 
> > use indirect encoding.
> 
> That's a good point.  In the real world, chromosomes don't have
sex, 
> organisms do.  So the speciation mechanism for an indirect encoding 
> scheme would probably need to base speciation on phenotype.
> 

I strongly disagree with this.  Species in biology are organisms that
share genetic history.  Those organisms in separate species share less
genetic history.  And the history is *genetic* and not phenotypic- and
genetic history is exactly what historical markings measure.  If you
give up on that, you are left with massive analytic problem of
comparing phenotypic morphologies and functionalities that are wildly
complex.  But why do that when we know genetic history?

I also disagree with the idea that changing a gene in indirect
encoding can have a huge impact on phenotype.  I think this is only
true in a *bad* indirect encoding.  In a good indirect encoding, such
as DNA, there is canalization, which means that it's difficult to get
massive perturbations in phenotype from small changes in genotype.  In
other words, the system is more or less robust to change on the macro
level.  It is important not to confuse current primitive indirect
encodings with the potentially powerful indirect encodings we will
ultimately use.  An encoding where flipping a bit can result in an
unrecognizable phenotypic mutant is terribly brittle, and should not
be the basis of our intuitions about complexification or speciation.

I do agree, it is still aquestion whether N should be used or not in
any encoding, whether direct or indirect.  I believe I've heard that
monkeys have 99% of the genetic history as humans.  Assuming this is
true, if we were normalizing for genome size, I think we'd conclude
that monkeys and people were in the same species!

The issue behind the best way to use N (perhaps some nonlinear
formula), if at all, is certainly an open question.  But I don't think
there is any future in comparing phenotypes instead of genotypes.

> > >That is, in the second case, a given species could
> > >have much more or much less topological difference
> > >between its individuals.  This approach seems less
> > >desirable to me, since it seems less
> > >biologically-inspired.  You're enforcing an arbitrary
> > >division of the population, rather than defining
> > >species primarily by a distance function.
> > >
> > >  
> > >
> > Agreed.
> 

One interesting question is how a DST would interact with a
normalization factor.  They may interact in interesting ways.
I agree that the DST is biologically implausible.  But it does
help in a practical sense, because you no longer how to worry about
species explosions or implosions, and I've found it quite effective in
a number of experiments.  That's not to say that there isn't
necessarily a better way.  Here are the options:

-No DST and no N
-DST and no N
-No DST and N
-DST and N

There is also the added issue of whether N should be made nonlinear in
some way, as I believe Colin suggested.

It may depend a bit on population size and on the complexity you are
aiming for which combination is best, and it's an open issue.
